document.docAuthor: Namyatova, Anna A. & Konstantinov, Fedor V.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Capsus hirtus Curtis, 1838: 693
(junior primary homonym of
Cimex hirtus Muller, 1776
; syn. by Herrich–Schaeffer, 1853: 14).

subSubSection.paragraph:
DIAGNOSIS: Recognized by the dark brown hemelytra (fig. 3), yellowish tibiae often paler than femora, dark brown antennal segment I, aedeagus with two spicules, long spicule straight, equal in length to dorsal wall of theca, short spicule curved, half as long as long spicule (fig. 8), dorsal labiate plate with medial sclerites almost triangular, somewhat longer than sclerotized ring (fig. 16). Most easily confused with
O. fulvipes
and
O. sefrensis
, but differing from both in the straight rather than twisted long spicule of aedeagus (compare fig. 8 and figs. 7, 9), and from the former by the dark brown antennal segment I. Apparently not separable from these two species by the structures of the female genitalia (figs. 15, 16, 17). Also similar in appearance to
O. bivittatus
, but that species can be separated by having the long spicule shorter than the dorsal wall of the theca (fig. 7) and the medial sclerites distinctly longer than the sclerotized rings (fig. 14).

REDESCRIPTION: Male : Macropterous, length 4.2–6.4. COLORATION (fig. 3): Head : Dark brown to black, with black, sometimes pale brown, smooth spot near inner margin and with pale brown or yellowish stripe along posterior margin of eye, sometimes this color-pattern indistinct; antennal segment I dark brown to black, segment II dark brown, sometimes paler at base; labium dark brown to black. Thorax : Pronotum dark brown to black; evaporatorium at least partly yellowish or pale brown, paler than pleurites; scutellum dark brown to black; coxa dark brown to black, rarely forecoxa somewhat paler than middle and hind coxa; femur dark brown to black, rarely pale brown or yellowish apically; tibia yellowish or orange, apically and basally darkened; hemelytra dark brown to black; membrane uniformly pale brown. Abdomen : Uniformly dark brown to black. SURFACE AND VESTITURE: As in
O. bivittatus
(as in figs. 22 A-C, E, 23 A, D). STRUC- TURE AND MEASUREMENTS: Body 3.3–4.3× as long as width of pronotum. Head : Shape of head and eye as in
O. bivittatus
(as in figs. 20 B, 21 A, G), 1.2–1.3× as wide as high; vertex 1.6–2.3× as wide as eye; eye located a short distance from anterior pronotal margin; antennal fossa located close to inferior margin of eye; antennal segment I as long as or somewhat longer than diameter of eye, segment II 0.8–1.2× as long as basal width of pronotum, 1.1–1.6× as long as width of head; labium reaching middle coxa. Thorax : Pronotum 1.7– 2.3× as wide as long and 1.2–1.5× as wide as head, with posterior margin straight or slightly concave, lateral margin not carinate, calli slightly raised; hind femur relatively narrow, approximately 1.5× as wide as middle femur. GENITALIA: Aedeagus with two spicules, long spicule straight, not twisted, somewhat dilated in apical third, with gradually tapering apex, nearly equal in length to dorsal wall of theca; short spicule clawshaped, gradually curved, about 1.5× as short as long spicule ( Fig. 8 ); parameres as in fig. 12.

Female: Brachypterous, rarely macropterous; length 3.3–4.8. COLORATION: As in male. SURFACE AND VESTITURE: As in male. STRUCTURE AND MEASUREMENTS: As in male, body 2.5–3.5× as long as width of pronotum. Head : 1.1–1.2× as wide as high, vertex 1.7–2.1× as wide as eye; antennal segment II 0.8–1.2× as long as basal width of pronotum, 0.9–1.3× as long as width of head. Thorax : Pronotum 1.3–2.2× as wide as long and 0.9–1.3× as wide as head with posterior margin distinctly concave; length of hemelytra ranging in brachypterous specimens from reaching abdominal tergum VII to covering entire abdomen, usually covering abdominal tergum VIII, cuneus slightly delimited, claval commissure as long as inner claval margin, posterior and lateral margins of hemelytra rounded or posterior margin sometimes truncate. GENITALIA: Sclerotized rings oval, medial sclerites almost straight, twin-coned, with extreme bases twisted and variously shaped, truncate (as in
O. fulvipes ,
fig. 15) or triangular apices, somewhat longer and narrower than sclerotized rings (fig. 16); posterior wall of bursa copulatrix with trapeziform sclerite uniformly sclerotized, incision on the anterior margin not reaching middle of sclerite, anterior angles of this sclerite somewhat dentate, posterior margin without sclerites (as in fig. 18,
O. bivittatus
); vulva with curved sclerites forming a circle (as in fig. 19,
O. vittipennis
).

DISTRIBUTION: Widely distributed in the western Palaearctic. The distributional range includes virtually all European countries and extends north to Norway , Sweden , Finland , Karelia Arkhangelsk , Perm , and Penza provinces of Russia , south to North Africa, Turkey , Caucasus, Iran , Kazakhstan , Altai, and Tuva, and east to Irkutsk province. This species was introduced to North America ( Henry and Kelton, 1986 ).

HOSTS: This species is undoubtedly polyphagous and has been collected from several plant families. It was recorded from the following species: Asteraceae :
Chrysanthemum sp.
( Reuter, 1891 ),
Centaurea maculosa Lam.
and
Cichorium intybus
L. ( Henry and Kelton, 1986 ),
Centaurea sp.
and
Hieracium pilosella
L. ( Wagner, 1974 ),
Hieracium alpinum
L.,
H. villosum Jacq.
,
H. racemusum Waldst. et Kit.
( Tamanini, 1981 , 1982 ),
Erigeron
and
Crepis spp.
( Tamanini, 1981 ); Fabaceae :
Vicia sp.
and
Trifolium sp.
( Reuter, 1891 ),
Ononis sp.
( Saunders, 1892 ),
Spartium
, including
Spartium junceum
L. ( Tamanini, 1981 ),
Lotus sp.
( Seidenstücker, 1959 ); Lamiaceae :
Thymus serpyllum
L. ( Reuter, 1891 ). Ehanno (1960) collected
O. saltator
from species of Poaceae and Linnavuori (1999) from unspecified species of Asteraceae . Some specimens from ZISP were collected from
Spiraea sp .
( Rosaceae ) by I. M. Kerzhner and
Salix sp.
( Salicaceae ) by an unknown collector.

DISCUSSION: In this species, sclerites adjacent to the sclerotized rings vary in shape and can be very similar to those of
O. fulvipes
(see fig. 15). Females of
O. saltator
are difficult to separate from
O. fulvipes
and
O. sefrensis
as both external characters and genitalic structures are similar. Refer to
O. sefrensis
for additional discussion of the issue.

According to the original description ( Reuter, 1891 ),
O. parvulus
is related to
O. saltator
, but differs in the smaller size, thinner antennae, antennal segments III and IV combined longer than segment II, less convex eyes, and more inclined cuneal fracture. Wagner (1974) also suggested that these two species can be distinguished by the body length and ratio of vertex to eye. The careful examination of all available material has showed that all mentioned characters vary greatly and are not useful in the separation of
O. saltator
and
O. parvulus
. No distinctions were found in the structure of both male and female genitalia. Therefore,
O. parvulus
is synonymized with
O. saltator
.

Two syntypes of
O. ferrarii
and a single syntype of
O. parvulus ,
belonging to the Reuter collection, Finnish Museum of Natural History, were studied in the course of this study. Here we designate the lectotypes of these two species. The lectotype of
O. ferrarii
, bears the locality label “Stazzano,” date and collector unknown and the type label “Spec. typ No 3504
Orthocephalus ferrari Reut.
” The lectotype of
O. parvulus
has the locality label “ Smyrna , 3.V.1871 , Krueper” and the type label “Spec. typ No 3510
Orthocephalus parvulus Reut.
” The scientific names of species on both type labels are written in the Reuter’s hand.
